title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: caugi (pronounced ‚Äúcorgi‚Äù) stands Causal Graph Interface. caugi small R interface fast Rust backend causal graphs. define graphs readable infix operators, query relations, keep R code nice tidy, Rust handles performance.

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: Causal graphs easy draw aid us understanding causal mechanisms visual representation. R, representing can feel clunky. usually resort adjacency matrices, edge lists, packages like igraph graph. packages great strengths, built causal graphs, often special edge types properties. way, adjacency matrices can hard read, especially since different standards exists representing different types causal relationships. example, even standardized, [,j] == 1 represents --> j j --> , represent PAG edge o->. people working causal inference causal discovery, can lead clunky, hacky code hard read maintain. caugi aims fix well thought, readable syntax, mimics draw graphs hand. makeshift solutions used represent causal graphs, leads bugs, confusion wasted time. caugi aim make causal graphs safe work , accidentally create invalid graphs, can focus causal problems hand, representation. caugi? caugi makes easy define, query, modify causal graphs R clean syntax fast performance.

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: caugi_graph bread butter caugi. easy create, query, modify. can create simple graphs well large number predefined graph classes. Currently, support "Unknown", "DAG", "PDAG". plan supporting several causal graph types future releases, "PAG", "CPDAG", "MAG", "SWIG", "ADMG".
code: # a tiny DAG cg <- caugi_graph(   A %-->% B + C,   B %-->% D,   C %-->% D,   class = "DAG", # optional, guarantees acyclicity by construction   simple = TRUE, # default   build = TRUE # build now; otherwise built lazily on first query )

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: %-->% directed %---% undirected %<->% bidirected %o->% partially directed %o--% partially undirected %o-o% partial can register types register_caugi_edge(), find need expressive set edges. example, want represent directed edge reverse direction, can like : expect feature needing polishing future releases, love input use feature!
code: register_caugi_edge(   glyph = "<--",   tail_mark = "arrow",   head_mark = "tail",   class = "directed",   symmetric = FALSE,   flags = c("TRAVERSABLE_WHEN_CONDITIONED") )  caugi_graph(A %-->% B, B %<--% C, class = "PDAG") #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 1 #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 A     #> 2 B     #> 3 C     #> 4 D     #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 3 #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 A     -->   B     #> 2 A     -->   C     #> 3 B     -->   D     #> 4 C     -->   D  # reset the registry to default with original edges reset_caugi_registry()

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: caugi graphs represented compact Compressed Sparse Row (CSR) format Rust. caugi works front loading philosophy. Since caugi graph stored CSR format, mutations graph computationally expensive compared graph storage systems, allows fast querying. Additionally storage format graph , caugi also stores additional information node relations way allows ùí™(1)\mathcal{O}(1) look-time many relational queries, nb(cg, ) ch(cg, B). accommodate cost mutations, caugi graphs built lazily. means mutate graph, example adding edges , graph edits stored R, Rust. need query graphs, graph rebuild Rust, query executed newly built graph. can also use build(cg) function force building graph Rust time.

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: Use + fan one side, c(...) parentheses group. Unconnected symbols also declare nodes:
code: caugi_graph(   X %-->% Y + Z, # X ‚Üí Y and X ‚Üí Z   c(Y, Z) %-->% W, # Y ‚Üí W and Z ‚Üí W   (A + B) %---% (C + D) # all undirected pairs across groups ) #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 1 #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 A     #> 2 B     #> 3 C     #> 4 D     #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 3 #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 A     -->   B     #> 2 A     -->   C     #> 3 B     -->   D     #> 4 C     -->   D caugi_graph(A, B, C) # declares three isolated nodes #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 1 #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 A     #> 2 B     #> 3 C     #> 4 D     #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 3 #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 A     -->   B     #> 2 A     -->   C     #> 3 B     -->   D     #> 4 C     -->   D

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: can query relations like parents, children, neighbors. can use symbols, characters, indices.
code: cg <- caugi_graph(   A %-->% B + C,   B %-->% D,   C %-->% D,   E %---% F,   class = "PDAG" ) parents(cg, D) #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 1 #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 B     #> 2 C children(cg, index = 3) #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 1 #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 D neighbors(cg, c(B, C)) #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 1 #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 A     #> 2 D     #> 3 A     #> 4 D

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: can check graph properties following functions.
code: is_acyclic(cg) #> [1] TRUE is_dag(cg) #> [1] FALSE is_pdag(cg) #> [1] TRUE

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: can add, remove, set edges nodes. Changes applied next query call build(). provide non-standard evaluation interface infix operators: can use standard evaluation: Besides add_edges, can also use remove_edges(), set_edges(), add_nodes(), remove_nodes(), set_nodes(), subgraph().
code: cg <- caugi_graph(   A %-->% B + C,   B %-->% D ) cg <- add_edges(cg, E %-->% F) cg <- add_edges(cg,   from = c("D", "G"),   edge = c("-->", "o->"),   to = c("E", "H") )

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: caugi utilizes S7 object system ensure mutation safety. means meant hard mutate graphs without using provided functions. ensure graphs always valid, accidentally create situations queries invalid graph invalid. S7 object system widely used yet, found S3 object system lenient, hard us ensure graphs queries always valid. found S4 heavy cumbersome work .

title: Introduction to `caugi`
text: plan adding following features caugi future: Graph classes: PAG, CPDAG, MAG, SWIG, ADMG, Adjustment sets, Structural Hamming Distance, Adjustment Identification Distance, d- m-separation queries, ‚Ä¶much !

title: Causal Graph Interface
text: Causal Graph Interface (R) ‚Äî fast, tidyverse‚Äëfriendly toolbox building, coercing analysing causal graphs. caugi (pronounced ‚Äúcorgi‚Äù) wraps high‚Äëperformance C++ core pipe‚Äëfriendly R interface. Convert many graph formats, compose graphs expressive infix operators, run algorithms large sparse matrices‚ÄØ‚Äî‚ÄØwithout leaving tidyverse.

title: Causal Graph Interface
text: caugi needs R¬†‚â•¬†4.2 C++17‚Äëcapable compiler. See ?caugi::caugi full details.
code: # dev version from GitHub install.packages("pak")         # if needed pak::pak("frederikfabriciusbjerre/caugi")  # ‚Ä¶or wait for the first CRAN release # install.packages("caugi")

title: Causal Graph Interface
text: Coercion works ways:
code: library(caugi)  my_graph <- caugi_graph(   tibble::tibble(name = letters[1:4]),   a %-->% b,   b %<->% c,   d %---% a )  print(my_graph) #> # A caugi_graph with 4 nodes and 3 edges #>   from to edge_type #> 1 a    b --> #> 2 b    c <-> #> 3 a    d --- ig <- igraph::make_ring(5, directed = TRUE)  cg <- as_caugi(ig)

what: How it works: compact CSR storage
title: Causal Graph Interface
text: Internally, every caugi_graph lives Compressed Sparse Row (CSR) form:
code: row_ptr    : int[n_nodes + 1] col_ids    : int[n_edges] type_codes : int[n_edges]   # maps 1‚Äë6 ‚Üí {"-->", "<->", ‚Ä¶}

title: Causal Graph Interface
text: ‚Äôre actively working : d‚Äëseparation queries (dsep()). Adjustment‚Äëset identification (adjustment_sets()). Graph distances ‚Äî Structural Hamming Distance (SHD), simple Hamming Distance (HD), Adjustment Identification Distance (AID), ! Additional causal metrics utilities. Want help? Open discussion!

title: Causal Graph Interface
text: Pull requests, issues feature requests welcome. Please open issue large changes.

title: Causal Graph Interface
text: tidyverse style; run styler::style_pkg() committing. PR must pass devtools::check() errors, warnings, notes.

what: caugi: A tidy interface to causal graphs ‚Äî caugi-package
title: caugi: A tidy interface to causal graphs ‚Äî caugi-package
text: caugi wraps high-performance C++17 core pipe-friendly R API. reads writes many graph formats (edge lists, igraph, graphNEL, pcalg amats, sparse/dense matrices) stores everything internally compact Compressed Sparse Row (CSR) structure.  result white-board syntax data-table speed‚Äîeven graphs millions edges.

title: caugi: A tidy interface to causal graphs ‚Äî caugi-package
text: package designed causal discovery graphical causal inference.  Edge codes cover DAGs, CPDAGs PAGs; helper functions let collapse mutual edges, round-trip igraph, coerce dense sparse representations without copy overhead.  Planned extensions include d-separation queries, adjustment-set identification, distance measures SHD/HD.

title: caugi: A tidy interface to causal graphs ‚Äî caugi-package
text: Readable construction ‚Äî %-->% b, b %<->% c, c %o->% d, ‚Ä¶ Blazing speed ‚Äî core algorithms modern C++ CSR caching. Format agility ‚Äî as_caugi() methods igraph, graphNEL, pcalg amats (CPDAG & PAG), sparse/dense matrices, tidy edge lists. Tidy output ‚Äî as_tibble() returns long edge list ready dplyr/tidyr workflows. Use igraph ‚Äî as_igraph() lets use igraph‚Äôs layouts plotting.

title: caugi: A tidy interface to causal graphs ‚Äî caugi-package
text: Frederik Fabricius-Bjerre frederik@fabriciusbjerre.dk,

what: Create a caugi_graph from edge expressions. ‚Äî caugi_graph
title: Create a caugi_graph from edge expressions. ‚Äî caugi_graph
text: Create caugi_graph series edge expressions using infix operators. Nodes can specified symbols, strings, numbers. following edge operators supported default: %-->% directed edges (‚Äì> B) %---% undirected edges (‚Äî B) %<->% bidirected edges (<-> B) %o->% partially directed edges (o-> B) %o--% partially undirected edges (o‚Äì B) %o-o% partial edges (o-o B) can register additional edge types using register_caugi_edge().

title: Create a caugi_graph from edge expressions. ‚Äî caugi_graph
code: caugi_graph(   ...,   simple = TRUE,   build = TRUE,   class = c("Unknown", "DAG", "PDAG") )

title: Create a caugi_graph from edge expressions. ‚Äî caugi_graph
text: ... Edge expressions using supported infix operators, nodes given symbols strings. Multiple edges can combined using +: --> B + C, indicating edge B C. Nodes can also grouped using c(...) parentheses. simple Logical; TRUE (default), graph simple graph, function throw error input contains parallel edges self-loops. build Logical; TRUE (default), graph built using Rust backend. FALSE, graph built, Rust backend used. graph build, queries made graph calling build(). Note: Even build = TRUE, edges nodes provided, graph built pointer NULL. class Character; one "Unknown", "DAG", "PDAG".

title: Create a caugi_graph from edge expressions. ‚Äî caugi_graph
text: caugi_graph S7 object containing nodes, edges, pointer underlying Rust graph structure.

title: Manipulate nodes and edges of a caugi_graph ‚Äî caugi_verbs
text: cg caugi_graph object. ... Expressions specifying edges add using infix operators, nodes add using unquoted names, vectors via c(), + composition. Character vector source node names. Default NULL. edge Character vector edge types. Default NULL. Character vector target node names. Default NULL. name Character vector node names. Default NULL.

title: Is the caugi acyclic? ‚Äî is_acyclic
text: Lazy building graph built, graph built making query. Check logic construction caugi_graph, graph class "DAG" "PDAG", graph guaranteed acyclic. graph class "Unknown", graph may may acyclic. force_check = TRUE, function check graph acyclic using Rust backend, matter class. graph class inherently acyclic, is_acyclic run check. Note think possible introduce cycle caugi_graph acyclic classes without package throwing errors. might wrong, though, force_check e feature peace mind.
